PEOPLE'S ASSOCIATION
(Commission of Inquiry)


    1. Mr David Marshall asked the Prime Minister whether it is the Government's intention to recommend the appointment of a Commission to investigate and report on the political aspects of the employment, activities and dismissal of the staff of the People's Association, both paid and voluntary, from its formation up to date, with particular reference to the stoppage of work and dismissal of employees of the Association since 20th July, 1961.

    The Prime Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, there are four Commissions of Inquiry which are being considered. The first is to inquire into the causes of the agitation over the Chinese middle schools' conversion from the 3:3 to the 4:2 system which led in particular to the organisation of an attempted boycott of the first Secondary Certificate Examination in December last year and with particular reference to the Communist cadres behind the scenes who are responsible for it all.

Column: 5



    The second is to investigate the events which developed into open insubordination and defiance of the authority of the Board of Management of the People's Association by some 130 workers out of 480 workers of the Association and to establish the connection between these persons, their leaders, and leading members of the Barisan Sosialis who had recruited these leaders whilst they were on the Board of Management of the People's Association.

    The third is the Commission asked for in the motion by the Member for Anson and the Member for Upper Serangoon to which the Government agrees, provided that all statements and allegations made in this Assembly by the two movers of the motion and by any other person who speaks in support of the motion be undertaken to be given in evidence on oath by such persons before the Commission of Inquiry.

    The fourth is asked for in item 13 of the Order Paper, to inquire into the content and administration of the education policy other than vocational and technical education, including the question of the six-day week. This Commission of Inquiry will, in response to a letter dated the 19th of December from the Member for Anson to the Minister for Education, also include the terms of the Member for Anson's letter, an inquiry into political activities and machinations in primary and secondary schools, the extent thereof, and the persons and organisations responsible therefor.

    Sir, it will not be possible at any one time to have more than one Judge available to conduct a Commission of Inquiry. It is the Government's intention to proceed with the first Commission of Inquiry as soon as a Judge is available, and then in turn with the other three.

    Mr David Marshall: Would the Prime Minister recognise that there is a distinction between what is sought in respect of the People's Association, particularly where it is requested that the Commission inquire into the political aspects of the employment,

Column: 6

activities and dismissals, and could the Prime Minister give us an indication as to when these Commissions of Inquiry would be appointed? Would he consider some person other than a Judge in respect of some of them?

    The Prime Minister: Sir, the subjects of the four inquiries are matters where it is more than likely that serious charges of persons and organisations being politically partisan will be made. I think, if the Commission of Inquiry is to have any value at all in commanding respect for its deliberations and for its recommendations, it will be difficult to find persons suitably qualified who are not politically coloured in one way or another other than members of the Bench.

    Mr David Marshall: If it please you, Mr Speaker, in the matter of education policy, surely it is not really appropriate or necessary to seek the chairmanship of a High Court Judge. We are rather anxious to ascertain when the Prime Minister considers it possible for the Commissions of Inquiry to start their investigations.

    The Prime Minister: I would agree with the Member for Anson that in the terms of the motion in item 13, it might be possible to have someone other than a member of the judiciary to conduct the inquiry. But since that motion was first introduced, he has written a letter dated the 19th of December to the Minister for Education. I know of the contents of this letter only today after I had drafted the reply to the answer to Question No. 1. The Member for Anson has asked for the first limb in the terms of his motion in item 13. But the second limb-political activities and machinations in primary and secondary schools - if I had used this word "machinations" it might be said that there again we are out to pin the Barisan Sosialis and their comrades down, but this is by a fair and impartial Member of the Opposition. I would hate to have it said that the findings of the Commission are valueless because the member who presided over the Commission was not completely disinterested in every party

Column: 7

political sense of the word. I think it will serve a useful purpose to have these machinations brought out into the open.

    Mr David Marshall: Can I ask a supplementary question?

    Mr Speaker: Yes.

    Mr David Marshall: I am much obliged, Mr Speaker. Would the Prime Minister consider then leaving the first part of that motion to a commission of educationists and public persons, and the second part of the motion to be attached to the terms of reference of the Commission which will be inquiring into the question of the boycott of the Chinese school examinations? Then we would have two separate inquiries into really one political field and one education field.

    The Prime Minister: This is quite a different turn in the presentation of the request for a Commission of Inquiry. If the Member for Anson will write in those terms to the Minister for Education, I am quite sure we will be quite happy to consider breaking up the two terms of reference, one purely on the content of the education and the other on the political activities which can go in with the school boycott.

    Mr Speaker: There is one question which has been asked - the time the Commission will start.

    The Prime Minister: The first Commission, namely, the one on the agitation of school children and the persons responsible for it, my latest information is that the case will be ready for presentation sometime in February. I hope the Judge will be available to commence deliberations in February.

NEW FREE-PISTON GENERATING MACHINERY IN ST. JAMES
POWER STATION


    3. Dr Thio Chan Bee asked the Prime Minister whether he is aware that the new free-piston generating machinery installed in the St. James Power Station is no longer functioning properly, and what steps will be taken to avoid any danger of a sudden shortage of electricity leading to blackouts and rationing.

    The Prime Minister: Sir, it is not a question of the St. James Power Station no longer functioning properly because the new plant has not yet been put into commission.

    A tender for the construction of a Free Piston Gas Turbine Generating Plant at the St. James Power Station was accepted by the previous City Council in March 1957 to replace the obsolete and worn out steam plant which was then no longer serviceable. Construction and installation was completed towards the end of 1959, but the City Council has not - I repeat - has not yet taken over the plant as it has not passed the reliability test because of faulty materials and the technical modifications necessary. Defective parts are being replaced by the manufacturers

Column: 9

free of charge. The plant is expected to be available for full commission by September 1962.

    As regards the maintenance of electricity supplies, the Pasir Panjang Power Station Extension Scheme is now in progress and a seventh 25,000 K.W. turbo generator is scheduled for completion in June this year. Furthermore, a new power station to meet the needs of industrial expansion is also being built and a World Bank loan is being sought for this. The consultants for this project are already in Singapore.

    The first phase of the new station is for plant capable of generating 60 M.W. which is scheduled for commission in 1965. With these developments, it is not expected that there will be any sudden shortage of supply in the future. On the contrary, our total generating plant, once installed, should enable us to meet our expanding needs, including the Jurong Industrial Development project. However, I may add that the failure of the free-piston plant has been a great disappointment. The new plant was intended for peak loads and there have been anxious moments lately on this account during peak periods. It is possible that these may recur again between now and when the extension scheme in Pasir Panjang is ready in June this year. It is doubtful if the City Council should have agreed to install a free-piston plant. They were advised in 1957 that such a plant had not been proved and tested on such a scale and that St. James was to be the biggest of its kind in the world, and the present City Electricity Engineer was opposed to this project. But, however, as I have stated we have not as yet taken over the plant.

    Mr Rajah: Sir, is the difficulty with the St. James Power Station not really one of improper supervision which has led to the present position?

    The Prime Minister: Sir, from time to time, I have been troubled by the faults of what has been going on. In fact, the City Electricity Engineer had been sent to the New Hebrides in order to restore his confidence in the free-piston engine - I was told - not because of the

Column: 10

improper supervision but because this was the first time that a free-piston engine was installed on such a scale and not by the original patentees of the free-piston engine. I do not understand the technical intricacies of the term "free-piston", but I am told that it is something quite new. It is a gas turbine and it was developed by the French. In 1957, Mr Chan Kum Chee - I think he was the Chairman of the Public Utilities Sub-Committee - was persuaded, in spite of The views of the City Electricity Engineer, to undertake this project. Tenders were called for to install a free-piston engine although it had never been attempted on such a large scale and the tender was given not to the original French patentees but to an English firm which was going to manufacture under licence. It had sent the best qualified men to supervise and install this machine and there had been an endless amount of trouble since the trial test. The City Electricity Engineer lost confidence in the machine. To restore it, the World Bank team, which was out here at that time studying our request for a World Bank loan for the industrial project we had in mind, recommended - I think the gentleman's name was Monsieur Shereschewsky; the Minister for Finance is not here but I think it was Monsieur Shereschewsky - that the City Electricity Engineer, Mr Fuiczek, be sent to the New Hebrides where they had installed a free-piston engine which works. Well, he has seen that one work. I am told he is quite convinced that given time and the necessary modifications and materials, ours will work and it is hoped that by September 1962 it will work. But it has nothing to do with supervision. It was the best that the firm had available and the pity was that it was not good enough because they did not invent the free-piston engine.

    Mr Rajah: Is it not correct that the work was undertaken sometime in 1958 for the first time when the P.A.P. was in power in the City Council under the guidance of Mayor Ong Eng Guan and the work really started then? If so, could the Prime Minister not inform this House - from the files in his

Column: 11

possession he will surely know - that this has resulted from improper supervision rather than from an improper decision of the City Council?

    The Prime Minister: I beg to differ, much as I would like to explain things away in such an easy and facile manner. I think I must be quite fair in saying that I am not suggesting that Mr Chan Kum Chee made an improper decision in giving the tender. All I am saying is that he was advised not to try something new and he went on to try it. The tenders and all were already completed when the P.A.P. came into the City Council in December 1957. The project was one which was already on the cards as far as the City Council which the P.A.P. inherited was concerned.

    Mr Rajah: If the Prime Minister has looked into the files - and I expect he has looked into them - would he not agree with me that it was not Mr Chan Kum Chee who made the decision but that it was the City Council as a whole that made the decision?

    The Prime Minister: I do not dispute that in the ultimate analysis it was the City Council as a whole, but it was he, as the Chairman of the Public Utilities Sub-Committee, who recommended this over the views of the City Electricity Engineer. As it turned out, he was wrong.

    Mr Rajah: Mr Speaker, Sir, if only the Prime Minister will look a little deeper into those files he will find that it was done on the recommendation of the then Electrical Engineer. Mr Fuiczek, who is now the present Electrical Engineer, was merely an employee of that Department.

    The Prime Minister: I will have further research done on the files for the benefit of all Members concerned in order that history can do justice and accurately apportion the blame which I am sure the manufacturers shoulder fairly and squarely.

Column: 12



    Mr Rajah: The Prime Minister has said that, as a result of the extensions at Pasir Panjang, the first intake of supply will be in 1965.

    The Prime Minister: No, June 1962.

    Mr Rajah: I beg your pardon.

EQUAL CONDITIONS OF SERVICE FOR WOMEN IN CIVIL
SERVICE


    5. Mrs Seow Peck Leng asked the Minister for Finance whether he will give reasons why Women Teachers, Principals, Lecturers and Inspectors of Schools are paid less than their male counterparts.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance (Mr S. Ramaswamy) (for the Minister for Finance): Can we take the next question together?

    Mr Speaker: If it is convenient. Question 6 will be taken together.

    6. Mrs Seow Peck Leng asked the Minister for Finance whether equal pay for equal work and parity in terms of service will be extended to all women in the Civil Service.

    Mr Ramaswamy: The reasons, as far as I can make out, are historical. This grade of officers have been paid less than their male counterparts as far as recorded history goes. This period includes, of course, the period of office of the previous Government when the colleagues of the hon. Member were in office. Nothing was done then even to examine whether there was any justification for a perpetuation of this differentiation.

    The Government received a memorandum last November from the People's Action Party Women's League. The memorandum draws attention not only to the women teachers, principals, lecturers and Inspectors of Schools but to all grades in the civil service. It is under close study in the Ministry of Finance. The examination of the ramifications of this subject has not been completed. I therefore do not wish at this juncture to anticipate what the final outcome will be. All I can say is that the

Column: 15

People's Action Party has stated quite clearly that it supports the principle of equality for women.

    Mr David Marshall: Hear, hear!

    Mr Ramaswamy: This principle will be implemented to the extent that circumstances and the resources of the State permit.

    Hon. Members will realise that the implementation of equal pay and parity of treatment for the whole of the civil service amounts to a major administrative and political reform of great significance. The importance of the subject demands that it be treated with due care and deliberation. It is not merely a matter of arguing the merits or demerits of individual grades of officers. We have to study what the effects would be not only within the civil service but in other sectors of the economy. We have also to study precedents in countries which have effected this reform to see just how and how far similar measures can be taken in Singapore.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Mr Speaker, Sir, I wonder whether the Parliamentary Secretary is aware that this question has been studied and considered by "men" Governments since 1948. It has been a question of negotiations between the Singapore Teachers Union and the Government since 1948, and the women are beginning to lose confidence in all the studies that the Government has been making. Would the Parliamentary Secretary he kind enough to give us an idea of when he thinks, very roughly, the Government will come to a decision?

    Mr Ramaswamy: I cannot answer that now, Sir.

    Mr David Marshall: Is the Parliamentary Secretary conscious that the reasons he has given seem to suggest that it is the desire to bury the subject under the soot of time? If not, would he indicate if there is, in fact, a Committee, or an individual, or a number of individuals, or just nobody studying the issue, but it is being carried benevolently in mind?

    Mr Ramaswamy: There is a Committee, Sir.

Column: 16



    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Sir, what Committee is that?

    Mr Ramaswamy: It is ministerial responsibility, Sir.

    Mr Rajah: Mr Speaker, Sir, is the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance aware that the City Council have, in fact, accepted the equality of status for men and women so far as work and pay are concerned, and have a long time ago implemented that principle?

    Mr Speaker: The question really gives some information to the Parliamentary Secretary. He may or may not know. Therefore, it is out of order on that score. But a supplementary question can, of course, put it in order.

    Mr Rajah: Is the Parliamentary Secretary aware that the problem is one of urgency because of the fact that the City Council employees have now been amalgamated into the Government service; and as the City Council have accepted equality in pay, does he say that it will take him years to study this question?

PROPERTY TAX ORDINANCE
(Amending legislation)


    7. Mrs Seow Peck Leng asked the Minister for Finance whether he will introduce a Bill to amend the Property Tax Ordinance for the purpose of exempting vacant property from property tax.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance (Mr S. Ramaswamy) (for the Minister for Finance): I have been asked to reply. During the debate on the Second Reading of the Property Tax Bill, the Minister explained the reasons why tax would be levied on vacant property. May I refresh the hon. Member's memory to what he said then? [Hansard, 29th December, 1960, col. 904]:

    `Today we know that there is a shortage of housing. It is very difficult to get accommodation at reasonable rents. There is no excuse

Column: 17

whatsoever for any large number of houses to go vacant for any long period of time. If that happens, it merely means that the landowners are charging too high a rent. This being the case, it is only fair, taking the long-term view of their net income, that they should be taxed during the periods when their property is vacant.'

The Minister also said that "where there is a surplus of housing and many houses are vacant, although the rents charged are reasonable ... there would be a case for reconsidering the position." The position today does not differ very much from the time the Property Tax Bill was introduced; just over a year ago. There is, therefore, no reason to exempt vacant property from property tax.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Mr Speaker, Sir, does the Parliamentary Secretary realise that the property tax on vacant property does hinder developers from developing? I have given reasons before and so I shall not waste the time of the House now.

    Mr Ramaswamy: This was dealt with during the debate on the Budget, Sir.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Mr Speaker, Sir, all that he said was that he would like to see me in the C.P.A. Room and have a chat over it. Would you take that as an answer to the question, Mr Speaker, Sir?

    Mr Speaker: I am not the Parliamentary Secretary, and I do not know. Mrs Seow, Question No. 8.

ABSENCE OF TEACHERS ON REOPENING OF SCHOOLS
(Request for statement)


    9. Mrs Seow Peck Leng asked the Minister for Education whether he is aware that when the schools reopened on 2nd January, 1962, some classes had no teachers and the children were told that a teacher would be available only after two weeks, and whether he will make a statement on the matter.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, the recruitment of new teachers for the opening of schools each year is a massive annual event. The recruitment of more than 1,300 new teachers for the reopening of the new school year on 2nd January, 1962, was officially begun with advertisements published in the local newspapers calling for applicants on 26th October, 1961. A record number of 11,713 application forms were issued, and 6,542 completed forms were returned. Twenty-three selection boards were then constituted to interview 5,370 candidates. The process of calling up hundreds of those considered suitable, replacing those who have since decided not to accept appointment, getting them to sign the various requisite papers, having them medically examined, and issuing letters of appointment and posting orders, are time-consuming factors.

    As the Member for Mountbatten is fully aware, all this volume of work was done within two months. But for the devotion and loyalty of the staff of the Ministry and the long hours put in by the Establishment arid Inspectorate staff, principals of schools and lecturers of the Teachers' Training

Column: 19

College, I think we should consider ourselves fortunate that only 85 vacancies were left unfilled when the schools reopened on the 2nd of this month. However, by the 10th, only 33 vacancies remained unfilled. Of the 33 unfilled vacancies, eight have been given up to today to accept offers of appointment. Seventeen, now working in other Ministries, are waiting to be released from their present jobs, and another eight to be found who would be willing to be posted to island schools.

    To ensure that more time could be given to processing of future applicants and to complete full posting of new teachers to schools for the beginning of each school year, it is proposed to advertise in August this year for 1963 recruitment of teachers instead of waiting till October, i.e. two months earlier than was done last year.

UNAUTHORISED HUTS
